40928918.review:
I may not be the most versed gamer in VR, my library of VR games is fairly small compared to hardcore fanatics and I haven't clocked that much time, but out of all the VR experiences and games I've had the privilege to immerse myself in Sprint Vector hands down comes out on top.

GAMEPLAY
Sprint Vector is similar to Climbey and Vivecraft in locomotion but much more - as they say - fluid and intuitive. I only experienced Climbey for the first time today and was left desperately wishing the controls were the same as Sprint Vector. SV just works a whole lot better on first impressions. The most dangerous part of the intuitive gameplay is that it makes you want to run forward, don't by the way lol. Jumping is still something I struggle with but it isn't needed for the basic courses I played, probably is for the more complex courses though but by then I'll have a handle on it. The tutorials are comprehensive, fun and easy to follow, so if there's a mechanic you struggle with the game is more than happy to help you. My personal favourite mechanic is the climbing and flinging mechanic and I sorta wish there were specific climb centric courses. I've only played three courses in single player though, so for all I know there are lol. The running, climbing and flying mechanics are extremely easy to use but drifting is certainly something that takes practice. But no matter what mechanic you need to use it doesn't feel like you're dragging the game, as challenging as it is to learn some of the mechanics (for me at least) and as challenging as the game is physically (for me at least) it doesn't feel like there's nothing I can do to improve which is a much welcome change from some of the glitchy VR games out there. The only downfall is turning, aside from drifting you actually have to turn your whole body to turn. I haven't figured out if you can go backwards yet either. So if you get stuck and need to go a direction other than forward or slightly to either side it can be a bit disorienting. This is, however, a very minor grievance that doesn't necessarily apply to those with better balance than me and honesly I don't know how I'd improve it.
8/10 (one of the best games for gameplay I've played on VR)

GRAPHICS
Graphically speaking Sprint Vector wins out yet again. Most VR games leave me feeling like I need something more, not because the graphics aren't impressive or because they don't immerse me in the space necessarily but because they don't feel like a 'game'. Sprint Vector's graphics have personality, the space comes alive while you're inside. Everything from the menu to the lobby to the transition screen make you really feel like you're in a virtual world and not a demo. Sprint Vector is the first game I've played on VR, including Rickality, that doesn't feel like a demo or a mobile game brought to VR. A lot of that has to do with the graphics, the voice acting, the design. It's all perfect and I wouldn't change a thing. It's everything I hoped for from a VR game.
10/10 (I'd give higher if I could)

FITNESS
Oh yeah, you'll sweat. It's extremely arm intensive though, your legs get barely any work at all so Spring Vector isn't exactly gonna replace leg day lol. Sorry guys. That being said it certainly makes my shoulders burn and my heart rate rise and because of the competitive nature of the AI (only played solo) it really pushes you to go harder and faster. The races feel a little long when you can feel the burn in your arms but when you hit that finish line, man is it worth it. Just makes you wanna go again to get an even better score. It doesn't feel like work and the commentary indicates how far through the course you are so you can push that little bit harder.
9/10 (For arms anyway, and for me... I'm pretty unfit so you'll have to see for yourself, but the work is definitely scalable.)
2/10 (For legs, just cause you have to turn and stand the whole time lol)
9/10 (For cardio, oh man...)

STORY
Well other than an immersive premise and world with engaging characters and stellar voice acting the game doesn't appear to have much in the way of story. This makes sense because the premise of the game is that it's an intergalactic game show with the player being a competitor. You get an idea of the kind of world and gameshow you're dealing with through the commentary and perhaps there's more story as you progress through the courses, made obvious by the commentary or something like that, but where I stand in the game having completed three courses the story is certainly lacking. This is shame because I absolutely flipping love this game and really want a story campaign. I would absolutely lap up any story the creators felt like adding in. I'm extremely interested in Mr. E and the world and the gameshow and everything and would appreciate a soft story like most fighting games. However, the bare minimum story that the game has is one that makes you want to know more, that makes it feel like the world is real, alive, breathing. The fact that the existing premise is so enticing is probably why it's so painful that the game doesn't really have a story.
7/10 (What's there is 10/10 but what's there makes me want so much more)

UI
Like all other points of design the UI is practically perfect. I've found with a lot of VR games the menus feel like they haven't been integrated well into the medium, Sprint Vector doesn't have this problem. It's believable to have this menu popped up in front of you and it's extremely easy to use. The hand that pops onto the menu to click things feels like an extension of your real self, which is good because that's what VR is all about. That being said, I've only played Single Player and haven't been able to find settings for the AI. I've been coping with it but I would like the ability to scale difficulty, as I am now the game is a little too challenging and as I get fitter I can imagine it becoming easy without scalable difficulty. That being said the store page does describe AI customisation in solo play so perhaps I'm playing the wrong mode. If, however, the settings exist in Single Player, I've been unable to find them. The settings and menus are extremely easy to understand and, for the most part, intuitive but where are the "customisable solo game settings"?
8/10 (best interface design of any VR game I've played)

POINTS OF IMPROVEMENT
The game seems diverse and the world extremely interesting so... I'm disappointed there's no story campaign! I really wish they could add one, I really do. The store page mentions AI settings being customisable but I've been unable to find the setting in the single player mode, maybe it isn't in that mode but if it is the intuitiveness of the settings needs improving lol. If it isn't then, well, I guess it's fine and I'm just playing the wrong mode. The only gameplay point that urks me is needing to turn, you can't turn without turning your body which can be... annoying and disorienting sometimes. All these points are extremely minor concerns (except the story, I really do want a story mode) and don't bring my ultimate score down too much but this is a review and so it needs to be picky.

OVERALL
Sprint Vector is by far the best VR game I've played. Hands down. All the "flaws" I've observed may just be me as well, might not even be the game, I'm not exactly a professional reviewer. All that being said I haven't played very much of the game, I can't comment on replayability or scale of difficulty or challenge modes or multiplayer or advanced courses because I haven't played them. This is almost a first impressions review, so take it such. /That/ being said though, I can't imagine my impression of the game changing, it's just so fun and engaging.
8/10 Highly recommend, rabidly recommend lol.

40603764.review:
I ragazzi californiani di Survios, reduci dal successo di Raw Data, puntano quindi su una produzione massiccia e (siano lodati) multipiattaforma, spinta particolarmente da Sony e che regala finalmente belle soddisfazioni anche ai possessori di HTC Vive ed Oculus Rift.

Sprint Vector è un titolo di corsa, ma non è il solito racing game. Nel medium videoludico siamo abituati alle corse a bordo dei mezzi più variegati, ma la corsa sulle proprie gambe è un qualcosa che non vediamo tutti i giorni (se non nello splendido Speedrunners). Probabilmente questo è dato dalla distanza tra pad e schermo, che fa optare gli sviluppatori per mezzi più stimolanti, ma grazie alla realtà virtuale anche la corsa a piedi (o quasi) viene finalmente sdoganata. Nel titolo di Survios, infatti, ci troveremo a correre come pazzi in sfide a più giocatori, accompagnati da una variante futuristica dei pattini a rotelle che sfrecceranno a velocità straordinarie, facendoci sentire nel corpo di un Usain Bolt 2.0.

Il sistema di locomotion di Sprint Vector è uno dei più riusciti in circolazione; per procedere dovremo simulare con le braccia una vera e propria corsa, premendo una combinazione semplice ed intuitiva di pulsanti che ci permetteranno di eseguire trick e movimenti impossibile da replicare fisicamente. Il solo sistema di locomotion rende il titolo una delle esperienze in VR più soddisfacenti disponibili sul mercato, che a fronte di un possibile rischio di motion sickness, regala comunque una libertà di movimento finalmente credibile ed immediata.

40599216.review:
Sprint Vector is a fantastic, absolutely must-have for any VR owner. While it may seem a bit challenging and tiring at first, once you play a few races and master the movement system the game has, you'll be tearing up each level the game has to offer like it's nobody's buisness. You do this by skating at super high speeds, jumping and flying over obstacles, and climbing up massive walls. Each level also has a lot of variety in its pathways and various obstacles. You can follow each level's main course, grabbing powerups and stopping anybody in your way, or, you could find the level's secret pathways and easily get ahead of everyone else. There are also a handful of challenge levels and time trials that you can do, if you ever get bored of racing. And of course, if you feel the AI is too easy, you can play online and face other people in a race, which I find to be way more challenging than the AI. The playerbase is decent and as of now, it seems as though you'll always be able to jump into a match.

Oh, also, it's a [b]complete[/b] VR game, unlike most VR games out there that cost like $40 and last only an hour.

40422381.review:
tl;dr - Do ALL the damn tutorials! It's much more fun if you know what you're doing.

I almost gave up on this after my first few races. It's incredibly frustrating in a racing game to constantly have all your speed wiped out, and that was happening to me constantly. But I'd only done the basic tutorial, and figured that was enough. I was wrong. It turns out some very essential things are in the subsequent tutorials, and they should not (in my opinion) be optional.

Now that I know what I'm doing it is much more fun, and as a bonus it's a great workout. 

Pros:
- Designed for VR
- Exhilarating play
- No motion sickness despite all the movement, at least for me.
- Bots are a reasonable substitute to fill when when there aren't enough human opponents

Cons:
- Even after doing all the tutorials and building some knowledge of the levels, I still feel like the game relies too much on the design style of "punish mistakes" rather than "reward skill". I'd love to see a shift in level design away from things that completely elminate your hard-won velocity, and instead add more things that reward you when you pull off a great jump, turn, or glide.
- Like any multiplayer game, the community is what makes it shine, but there's something about esports that brings out the worst in some people. It's only a small step from good-natured trash talk to being a total asshole, and sadly I've already run into a number of players who fall on the asshole side of things. There's absolutely no need for it, especially in a game with a small community. Luckily the game makes it easy(ish) to mute and "hide" people, but I wish I didn't have to.

Sprint Vector isn't a bad game, but I do not recommend it due to several reasons. The tutorial is not well done at all. Of course this is my personal view, but for a fast paced game where you need to learn several things to enjoy the game, the tutorial was way too long. The game mechanics should be more gradually introduced because if you get through a long tutorial and the first level needs to be played a few times to get good at the game because of all the things you need to do quickly to play it, it is not well done. Tutorials should never be long. 

Since you have to jump, slow down, speed up, etc...some combination of buttons will take a screenshot, and a dialog box will block your view. I don't think this is the normal screenshot hotkeys that I'm used to from SteamVR, but possibly one within Sprint Vector? I constantly had screenshots messing up my game and was usually in last place because I kept getting a dialog box popping up. 

I do love a good workout in VR but this one just didn't feel good. It only works a few muscles specifically and they hurt after a short period of time. 

So all in all I do not recommend this game.

40259906.review:
I want to recommend this game SO BADLY, but I just can't. I will immediately admit that there are probably a lot of people who will love this game, and that's great, but this game just isn't for me unfortunately.

There are two significant problems for me: 
1. The controls.  One of the reasons I love VR where I didn't love regular video games is that in VR I don't have to memorize a whole bunch of button presses.  Controls are intuitive in VR.  In Sprint Vector, the running motion (pumping your arms) should be enough, but they've added the requirement of pressing the trigger too.  You have to press the trigger to run and press the touchpad while pumping your arms to jump and grab the trigger and touchpad to drift.  And braking requires hitting both side buttons, which is weird and uncomfortable (I've always hated those side buttons).  All the buttons are annoying to remember and I can't count the number of accidental screenshots I've taken.  

Those things make the game less fun, but I think I could have gotten used to it if it wasn't for the second issue:

2. Motion sickness.  I've got hundreds of hours in VR at this point, and no game has ever really made me sick the way Sprint Vector has.  I put on the comfort options in the game, but I still can't run more than one (maybe two) challenges before I have to leave the game.  And for the rest of the day I feel dizzy and disoriented.  I have tried over the last few days to let myself get acclimated to the motions, but the discomfort just isn't worth it.  Others clearly don't have this issue, so this might simply be a case of this game simply not being for me, but if you are sensitive to motion sickness, be wary of this game.

I wish I could recommend this game.  Unfortunately, even with more intuitive game controls, I just don't think I'd be able to play it due to the motion sickness issues.  

I will say though that this game is polished, and when I was able to play, a lot of fun.  If the buttons don't bother you and you don't have the motion sickness issues, you might give the game a try.

40202169.review:
Disclaimer: I was part of the closed beta. I'll be updating after I've spent a bit of time with the proper release.

#Overall: I had a ton of fun in the closed beta and I will absolutely be buying (have bought) this game. It's a blast despite minor hiccups that seem fixable. DONT EVEN THINK ABOUT IT -JUST GRAB IT. It's really the only game I can think of that's mastered this sort of motion, feeling of speed, strong tactics and exhilaration. It's the best experience I've had other than Superhot VR.

#Controls: The controls are fairly intuitive. The tutorials are HUGELY helpful at getting you to be comfortable with the controls and motions before even jumping in to a race. I WISH MORE VR GAMES DID THIS. Otherwise, each movement feels easy to grasp but tough to master. My only complaint would be climbing - it just feels awkward and I always lose ALOT of momentum at the top of a climbe as there is basically no way to propel yourself forward off the top off a climb. You just pop up and then start skating forward. Seems like a place for improvement.

#Graphics: Feel just right. Definitely an arcade SSX-vibe, which I think fits this type of game perfectly. Great variation of character design. Very well executed. Ran smoothly on my i5 with 1060.

#Sound: Basically same as graphics - super well done with lots of jokey, well-narrated and executed VO. SSX-like, for sure.

#Level Design: The three levels available to us were all distinct, with a number of interesting short cuts and different paths. The items really bring a lot of variation to the races - though I wish it was more evident what item you pick up each time. I almost had no idea what I was picking up and shooting.

#Other: PHYSICALLY TAXING. I'm not heavy and though I don't regularly excercise (but do bike regularly) and this left my arms SORE nearly everytime. It's just a highly repetetive motion (with occasional breaks to jump, etc.). This is not a bad thing! I actually enjoyed the soreness but it can limit your playtime.

40189207.review:
Sprint Vector is VR in perfection! 
It's a refreshing, fast paced, easy to learn but hard to master racing game that also requires physical effort.

The whole locomotion system is just incredible and I haven't seen it in any other game before. To get moving you have to swing your arms up and down - the faster you do so the faster you will get moving ("Freedom Locomotion VR" is a free Steam VR app that showed off this kind of armswing locomotion before). But that's only the basic movement, you can drive around curves by physically turning or by drifting (which you can do by pressing some buttons on the controller). The game also includes climbing (with comparable mechanics of the game "Climbey") and flying. There are powerups you can pick up during the game including different types of mines, boosters and rockets.

12 racing tracks as well as 9 challenge maps are included at the moment. Also there are four well made tutorials with video instructions so that everyone should understand it even if you haven't played any VR before. It will be easily possible to complete all the tracks after that but to get through them nice and smoothly and to know all the shortcuts it might take some more time (which motivates to keep playing). 
You can play in singleplayer with bots, challenge maps or in online multiplayer with up to 8 players.

So content-wise I don't want to complain but for long time motivation it would be great to have some more tracks in the future or even custom map support (that would be the best option if you'd ask me).

To sum it up, Sprint Vector really suprised me because of the innovative but  intuitive controls. 
It's a high quality VR game and feels very polished, I've yet to encounter any annoying bugs.
Get ready for sweating a lot and for your arms to get ripped! 
If you own a VR system you really do not wanna miss this game, it's one of the best you can get right now.

40135602.review:
Basically Mario Kart meets Speedrunners but in first-person and VR.

+ One of the most polished and refined VR games to date
+ Involves a lot more than just swinging your arms.  You really get to use a combination of body and arm movements and button presses that gives it more depth and skill than you'd think.
+ Great visual style
+ In-game comfort and tracking options.  I personally didn't have any motion sickness with this game despite the insane amount of movement and speed.  This is probably due to the fact that you have to physically act out the running to an extent so it feels more like you are causing the movement rather than the game moving you.
+ Decent amount of tracks and extra challenge levels and the developer has said more content is on the way.
+ Great upbeat electronic soundtrack
+ Solid performance for me on my entry level to mid range VR setup.  I did get some jitteriness during the tutorials though, which I think was due to the videos that were embedded into the game world.

- There isn't any kind of story or career mode.  This would have been a great opportunity to add a bit of story to each of the playable characters while also have some meatier solo content.
- Unlockables are pretty limited, only offering a couple of skin recolors for each character that are unlocked by completing solo content.  It would have been nice to see a system that encourages playing multiplayer more with unlockable content.
- Larger playspaces are ideal, being wired can get in the way too depending how you have things set up while swinging your arms.

40119324.review:
I've never written a review for a game before, aside from my Team Fortress 2 review a few years ago to get the badge, but let me tell you that I have never felt no game more deserving of praise and success. This has, within two days mind you, managed to become one of my all-time favorite games. It is easily the most immersive VR game that I have played as well as the most fun. I have met countless people who I already love hanging out with and it's so much fun to simply go online in a quick match, start racing with people and joking with them throughout the race and then laughing about all the great moments at the end of the race. 



   The game looks and feels amazing. I love the aesthetic and it just oozes charm once you're inside headset. It feels great to have the colors blur past you as you're sprinting towards the finish line. There is no feeling in the world as good as racing head-to-head at the finish line, trying any way that you can to just pass your opponent, tilting your head down and just giving it your all. Or, better yet, when you get a power-up midway through a race and realize the perfect spot to place a trap, listening to everybody behind you laugh and shout at your clever antics. 


   Another obvious point that has to get brought up is how much of a workout this game actually is. I am a person who almost never sweats, no matter the activity. Once I boot this game up though, within a couple of races, I'm drenched and chugging back water bottles out the wazoo. Your muscles will almost guaranteed be sore, even if you are in good shape. When I woke up the next day after playing 4 hours the first day, I could barely move my arms. The worst part is how much I was loving it. This is single-handedly, the most entertaining way to work out. Even though I was in pain from playing the game, I couldn't resist the urge to just boot it up that same day I felt sore and crank out another couple of hours. 40093588.review:
OVERALL: [9/10] This game is amazing. The quality of the game is superb and the visuals are incredible. Just the loading screen alone I don't want to skip because I love the transitions in the game. Would definitely recommend for anyone looking for a good arm workout and quick sweat session (HAVE A FAN GOING). 

CONTROLS: [8/10] The controls do take a bit to get used to. I only have an hour in the game so far and the controls are a little tough to get used to sometimes because if you are used to other climbing games and such, their controls are a  little different. There NEEDS to be an option to switch the movement direction from Headset to Controllers because I'd like to look behind me while running to check how far the other players are behind me. The powerups are a little hard to use because you need to guess where your shot is going to land because even with the small beams that come from your hand, its still hard to adjust for enemy speed and remember what kind of powerup you have.

CONTENT: [8/10] There is enough content for hours of playtime, such as challenges, singleplayer courses and online options, as well as competing with friends and other players in the world to see who gets the fastest speed or quickest time. I'm almost positive they will be rolling out more content but as for now, it's pretty basic; as to be expected from a newely released game.

FEEL: [10/10] My god the fluidity of motion, the thrill of getting full speed and keeping it makes me want to keep playing. The Grip Fields are something I personally have never experienced in a game before and they amaze me everytime, and I usually restart my race if I miss them because of how helpful they are. 

VISUALS: [10/10] The look of the game is unlike anything I've ever seen yet in a VR title. It has this 70's retro/futuristic vibe to it that works incredibly well with this type of game, and the characters (though they are a lil funny looking) all have different personalities and outfits that suit their persona. The glow coming off of your body and the environment are just incredible, and no levels are exactly the same, so it doesn't feel repetitive each time you race. There are different heights, shortcuts and obstacles that keep each map from feeling the same.

40093063.review:
Try this if you want to lose water weight... or arms.

Sprint Vector is a pretty astounding game worthy of its rating, combining theatrics, gameplay, and intuitive controls to make everything feel "just about right". The game is a cool VR take on speedrunning games such as, well, SpeedRunners, along with various Garry's Mod, Roblox, and Minecraft gamemodes of yesteryear. Using this simple racing concept, Sprint Vector kicks up the production value and really gets you looking autistic as you swing your arms up and down for your near-fucking life. The aesthetics are colorful and fun, most of the characters are only slightly annoying, and this game looks polished enough to eat off of.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Not very hard to understand, you just simply race on a map with 7 other people filled with the usual kart-racing assortment of secret paths and powerups. What you see is what you get.

[h1] Content [/h1] 

*Looks at Box*

Contains:
-x8 Characters (with a currently-small amount of skins for each)
-x21 Maps 
-x12 Tracks (not totally sure what the difference is between maps and tracks yet)
-x9 Powerups

[h1] Controls [/h1]

Probably the best part about the game, since despite the fact that the controls are very simple, they managed to fit a lot into the VR's lacking control scheme. This includes, but is not limited to:

-Sprinting (of course)
-Turning
-Drifting
-Jumping
-Flying
-Climbing
-Obstacle-Blasting
-Powerup-Using
-Stopping

While turning your camera with a wired headset can get annoying at times, everything else works smoothly.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

I got this game like an hour ago so i can't say too much about it yet, but it really hits all the right marks in terms of presentation and feel. If you think you'll like it, you probably will

40092658.review: Learning curve is a bit stiff (along with you arms the day after), but once you start to get better the game becomes incredibly fun.

Was really hesitant because the studio Survios made it. After my disappointment with Raw Data, I thought "man this better not be complete trash, ehhh I can always get a refund"... and bought the game on an impulse.

I am happy to report that this game is in fact not trash. In fact, with proper support this game could be the mario kart of VR. The maps have the same over the topness and it has power ups and all that jazz. Makes for a very fun experience. The game is easy to pick up but hard to master. So if you dive straight into multiplayer without learning how to drift in mid air, then uhh good luck...

Bottom line, pick it up. Easily worth $20, will make you sweat, lose weight, and you'll have fun doing it. If you've played climbey or to the top its pretty similar but it combines a much better locomotion mechanic for movement.

40090374.review:
You can't compare it to anything else in VR, because there is nothing like it in VR.  The best game you can compare it to is probably Mario Kart. All the mechanics are pretty robust, there's a strong multiplayer element, great visuals, and it's fun as sh*t.  There's nothing else like slowly gaining on another player, watching them look back in panic, and the intense competitive feeling you get from these interactions.  It's one of those things that simply doesn't work in anything but VR, since the degree of immersion brings all these elements to another level.

I do have a few gripes though.  Some parts of the map, say you get thrown off the beaten path by someone's powerup or an explosive barrel, are far too difficult to navigate.  There needs to be a button press or combination that teleports you to the center of the track.  I find way too often that I get stuck in between some level props that don't have any benefit to the track.

All in all it's a great experience.  I'd say that this is the VR title many people have been waiting for.  If a larger, more capable studio was smart enough to create stuff like this then VR would be taking right the f*ck off.

40089905.review:
[h1] Greatness Awaits! [/h1] 

   I'm getting sore and sweating more so than playing BOXVR with this masterpiece. The game's super unique with a Jet Set Radio vibe to it and a Mario Kart-level of fun, only in VR. It definitely feels like a "complete" and "polished" VR game, unlike a lot of gimmicky VR games where you repeat yourself in a manner that could become tedious. But this is a game that forces you to run, jump, dodge, duck, fly, climb, grind, and shoot as you rush through the course you're on. The workout aspect of this game, which is integrated and disguised in the fun you're having, is something that's desperately needed now more than ever with the obesity epidemic we so often ignore. And yet, as with all immersive, truly great games, the experience drowns away your bodily senses when you're steeped in it; but with this game when it's over you get that great feeling--as if you've just finished a workout and did your body a favor.

11/10. I rarely give reviews but with this game I felt obligated having paid the sale price of $23.99... when this is a game that's clearly worth much more.

40076477.review:
Sprint Vector is quickly becoming one of my favorite titles for the Vive. A fast paced, technicolor cross between SSX, Jet Set Radio, and Mario Kart is something I have (literally) dreamed of for years... and I even get it as a perfectly polished VR title? Game gods be praised.

Sprint Vector's gameplay is unique among titles I've played for several reasons-- the locomotion is perfect (ever been rollerblading? do that) in that it delivers the feeling of lots of speed with none of the nausea; the graphic design works perfectly with the hardware of the Vive, not too complex, but absolute eye candy at any given time with no distortion or screen door effect; and the nostalgia factor for any fan of SSX or JSRF is absolutely off the charts. I fell in love with the female race announcer after the first race, and the soundtrack is mostly top-notch electro, neuro-funk, drum-and-bass style beats that seem reactive to the player. 

The tracks are themed and designed well, with hidden passages and power-ups familiar to any player of karting games. I hope to see more tracks released in the future as DLC, and I haven't gotten into online multiplayer yet, but thus far, I have found absolutely nothing negative about this game. The design, gameplay, soundtrack, and overall effect of the game is delightful.

40036875.review:
It's finally here! I've been waiting a very long time for this game to finally release.

https://youtu.be/MNiZDoVIavA

I still remember my first match with Zeshin at PAX East 2017. Back when we had 1 map a red guy and a blue guy. I knew this game was going to be gold. Survios didn't disappoint!

You get a very quick intro tutorial that you can't skip but it's over very quickly. If you don't need it, under 40 seconds. That leads you into a pretty amazing intro sequence where you get to meet Mr. Entertainment face to face. This was an amazing touch that blew me away.

Visually the game looks great. If you stop and take a good long look at things, you might notice that they're a bit low poly but if you're taking the time to stop and stare at the roses, you're losing... The games art style fits the fast pace of the game perfectly.

The audio is also well done. From just the standard BGM to the voice acting and flavor commentary throughout the race, it's all very well done. The flavor commentary can get stale after a few hours of hearing the same line about Mud Bars but there's only so much dialog they can't reasonably record. That being said, they might pipe up a bit too frequently for the number of lines there are.

The controls are fairly easy to pick up but very difficult to master for some. There's a lot of fine movements or combinations of movements that will give a skilled player a distinct advantage over someone just flailing their arms. However, the arm flailing will mostly work and get you from point A to B. This is something that you'll want to run through the tutorials for just so you can get some practice. You'll also likely want to practice in the lobby which is a very large skate park that you can explore whlie queuing up for a game.

All in all, this game is a hell of a lot of fun and definitely worth the $29.99  (as of this write up, $23.99 after 20% off sale.)

What are you waiting for? Grab a Mud Bar and a Sidekick and go race!

40035982.review:
Yes, AAA , eSport, fluid, fast paced, well crafted, with well thought out tutorials.

It will take a little while to get your muscle memory down. Yes your arms will be moving a lot. Yes you may have to build up some endurance for it. I've already gotten my VR legs in "Intense" car racing and flight games so I no longer have a good reference point, but this seems like a "moderate" title to me.

I love the scale in this game. You are frequently in wide open spaces that look great. 

You are skating, but you also jump, climb, fly, drift, shoot and deploy various power ups. These power ups are of a number of types. There are boosts that affect your speed, there are mines that you drop behind you for players behind you and things you shoot at players ahead of you.

Because of this there is a lot of room to grow in this game and the multi-player competitions will become heated.  You need endurance, skill, coordination and a little strategy in terms of when and where to deploy various power-ups. It also helps to learn the tracks just like in a car racing game.

I'm still getting the hang of it, but the depth of the game is already obvious and it is a lot of fun to play.

drift speed may be a tiny bit slow, but that's more of a personal peeve.
half of the stages might seem to be simply reversed variants. although it changes up the game pretty well so that's not a big deal.

comfort notes:
i play a lot of video games, and i love things that move fast and play hard. this is no exception for VR games and this is exactly what i wanted.

      This game is pretty intense and may not be for people who dont like a good workout, because skating is basically moving your arms in a running motion, and jumping is a jumping motion. 
      Now while i say the above, that's slightly part of the reason im annoyed at the drift speed, because they have snap turning when i want it smooth. but i can understand why they choose to have snap turning and keep drifting slow and smooth. at this point is just game strategies.

i also reccomend playing this game standing up with some good air circulation going on otherwise you may find out how hot it can get under your headset lol. although i think i seen some people that play it sitting down...


long story short, this might be the best vr game i ever played. and im hoping for more hardcore platformer race stages in the future!



ALSO a great thing to note is. im playing under the minimal specs, i have a gtx 960 and the game plays fine for me 95% of the time. (Although i do have a pretty strong cpu and motherboard tho)

if i had friends who own a vr thing, i'd buy this for them.

40010851.review:
Firstly: Be prepared to get tired - and to hurt the next day. Make SURE you play something medium impact 
(like audioshield) as a warmup for 5-10 mins, otherwise your muscle attachment sites in your arms, shoulders and maybe chest will get hammered. You will be moving your arms fast and contantly from the start of the first race. The only reason I haven't played more is because I jumped in raw and I've been waiting for my muscles to repair before I play another session.

Anyway: This game game is great!

The controlls are responsive and well designed, so when you make mistakes it feels like it's your own fault.... and you WILL be making mistakes, because there is a learning curve for the controls. You will know what they are, but pulling off what you want to be a speedy arm swinging badass isn't exactly easy.

The courses are varied and will also take time to master... a lot of it! There are faster ways to take most sections of the courses if you execute properly, and plenty of shortcuts that you can take if you know what you are doing. It's the kind of game that you do better at when you gain actual skill rather than through leveling up.

The weapons will take time to be good with. When you first start, it's hard to notice what weapon you have, or even what it does - and there are a lot of them! Expect to just be firing stuff off not knowing what power-up you have until you learned your weapon icons through playing and practicing on the weapons practice area.

Speaking of which, there are great, well produced, tutorials that get you prepared well for starting playing. There's a weapons practice area that you sprint around in soaking up information and getting practice in using them.

I didn't get any motion sickness at all, and I played long enough to know that I wont. Almost all the time your brain accepts your arm movements to explain the motion, but on rare cases some things can happen that are a little jarring - but it does feel like you would adapt to feel comfortable in those moments.

All in all, a great VR game that's simply on another league that most VR releases. An excellent game that understands all that it needs to, to be a great VR game.

39981123.review:
50個近くVRゲームを所持しています。ほとんどが有料のもので、売り上げ上位でメジャーなものからマイナーなものまで。
7月にVIVEを手に入れてから数々のVRゲームをしてきました。無料ゲームも含めほとんどは面白かったのです。
しかし...しかししかし....

このゲームは違う。
数か月前に開発中という記事を見て知ってはいたが、まさかこんな急にプレイできるようになるとは思ってもいなかった。面白い。面白すぎる。頭がおかしくなる。ついでに腕もおかしくなる。
次元の違う面白さがある。


まず、チュートリアルの時点で2000円の元が取れる体験ができた。
走るためには腕を振る。一定の高さから速度をつけて交互にブンブン。陸上の走りよりはスピードスケートをイメージした方がいい感じに走れると思う。身体をひねったりして楽に早く走れる方法を探してる。
パッド押し込みでジャンプができて二段まで可能。片手ずつ空気をつかみ飛び越えるようにね。
同じ操作を横にすればサイドにもステップできる。空中両手トリガーで勢いに乗って滑空ができるぞ。
ブレーキはグリップボタン。空中だと重力ブレーキができて早く着地できるぞ。ゴールしてすぐキキィィィイとブレーキをするのは最高に気持ちが良かった。俺カッケェ。
実はドリフトなんかもできる。イメージは片手を地面に擦りつけながらターンする感じ。強度もコントロールできるので感覚の慣れが必要だ。ちなみにもう片方の手は振ってスピードを維持しよう。
途中で妨害アイテムやバフアイテムが手に入る。追尾ミサイルなど一見強そうにも見えるが、うまく発射しないと障害物に当たってしまうので妨害にも一苦労だ。他にもクライミングアクションなどステージギミックはは盛りだくさん。

リリース直後にしてはステージ数もモードも多い。かなりやりごたえがある。ステージのショートカットルートがわんさか用意されていて開拓が楽しい。タイムアタックが捗るね。


２時間半ぶっ通しでシングルとマルチ両方で走っていたのでもう腕がヤバい。みんな言ってるけど、やんばい。マルチプレイにはシングルにない程よい緊張や負けねえからな！って闘争心がアツく燃える。今日のハイライトは外国のお兄さんとラストスパートガチンコダッシュで0.03秒で負けたことかな。終わって握手してた。

唯一欠点？かどうかわからないけど、気になったのは、コースアウトやダウンしたときのリスポン時間が長いような気がした所。あれくらいなのかな？壁に挟まってコースアウトか微妙なラインではメニューを開いてチェックポイントワープしないといけない。メニューボタン二回押したらリスポンとかだったら変なコースアウトし方しても大丈夫そうだけど実装されなさそう！
コースアウトしなかったらいいんだよ！！って自分でも思うけど、急カーブ失敗すると慣性でへんなとこいっちゃうよ。ああ難しい！

VIVEコントローラーの機能をフルで活かして本当に多彩なアクションが可能になっている。操作に慣れたらもうあなたは超人。異能力者。ラノベ主人公。青いハリネズミ。
まさに小学生中学生高校生の時に妄想していたハイパーな自分がそこにはいる。


トレイラーやYoutubeの海外実況動画でなんとなく面白そうなのは伝わると思う。でもそれは30%程度しか伝わっていないと思うので買ってください。とりあえず買ってください。そして息を切らして、筋肉痛になって手汗びっしり額もぶっしょりになってください。手汗に関してはサイクリング用のうっすい指ぬき吸汗グローブをすればいいよ。




最後に。
このゲームは間違いなく売れる。死ぬほど疲れるけど死ぬほど面白い素晴らしいゲームだ。いつかVRのキラーソフトなんて呼ばれる日が来ることを祈るよ。

I really like this game since it is a workout. I usually play BoxVR for about 20 minutes to get some light cardio in and raise my heart rate. This game beats my heart rate in BoxVR for like 80% of songs I box too in my library. It's definitely different and there are some things I hope they fix. However, the polish is amazing and the game mechanics for the most part work.

If you like Mario Kart and physically active games this game is both of them combined. 

Personally, I'm not the biggest fan of kart racing games, but I love the physical intensity of this game as a workout. As well as racing makes you want to win over other players so you notice your tiredness less while playing. It's WAY more fun than a treadmill or other traditional cardio options.

The only cons that I really see right now is I get disconnected from lobbies occasionally and I'm not sure why. As well as the jumping mechanic is pretty weird since it seems to take awhile to finish the full motion. Many times I fall into pits since I don't release it correctly or don't make a long enough vertical motion making me fall. It's pretty hard to concisely hit the vertical motion for jumping with the touchpad when you're trying to skate as fast as possible. I wish maybe the jump would change to the same motion as skating, but with the touchpad instead of a perfectly vertical motion with the touchpad.

It's not a perfect game, but it is definitely worth a purchase. The level of polish, level design, and population (since it's new, so it's pretty easy to find other racers) is pretty good. I also like that if there are like 3 out of 8 players it just fills in bots so it doesn't feel so empty.

I would recommend purchasing it and trying it out and if you don't like it refund it, but I have a good feeling you will like it and keep it!

TLDR: This is a physically intense game that oozes with polish and is worth purchasing. There are few other VR games that are this unique and polished on Steam right now.

う、腕が痛い…一風変わったスプリントレースゲームです。
「Raw Data」を製作した会社だけあって面白いんだけどホント疲れる。
単純に走るだけかなーと思ったら全然違った。
壁をよじ登ったり、空飛んだり、アイテム拾って他のプレイヤー邪魔したり色々忙しい…。

操作方法についてはチュートリアルにてスプリントから障害物の対処方、飛行訓練、アイテム説明など実写動画付きで説明があるので、英語がよくわからなくても大体理解できる。

基本のスプリント方法は正面にコントローラーを向けてトリガーを引きながら体の側面へ下ろし、腕を下ろし切った場所でトリガーを離すと前に進みます。
（正面にあるバーを掴んで自分に引き寄せる感じ。）
これを左右交互に行うと走る。
スピードを上げたい場合は早く腕を動かすより、腕の可動域いっぱいに動かした方が速度上昇が良い気がします。

ゲームモードはシングルとマルチ、それと規定コースを走るチャレンジの３つ。
初めはシングルでコースを覚えてからマルチがいいかな。
シングルでもCPUが強いのでやりごたえは十分ある。

マルチはクイックマッチとプライベートの二つ。
クイックのマッチングは試合途中のロビーに入るので、接続の待ち時間はあまりない。
試合が終了したらマップ選択からの試合開始。
特にラグは感じず快適です。

かなり体力を消耗するので運動不足の自分には良いかも。
[strike]今ならサントラもついてくるのでお勧めです。[/strike]

39949658.review:
¡Has sido seleccionado para participar en el gran evento universal del Campeonato Intergaláctico Sprint Vector! Una muchedumbre espera en el estadio a tu presentación a manos de Mr.Entertainment. Mientras vuela por el interior del gran estadio, va calentando a los espectadores hasta que finalmente os reunís en su plataforma. Un micro se abalanza sobre ti desde el cielo para que digas unas palabras. ¡Los asistentes enloquecen! Sin darte mucha cuenta, ya has elegido a tu personaje y tienes a los demás corredores a tu alrededor, la carrera va a comenzar. Solo queda que consigas esquivar todos los obstáculos del camino y los que te pongan tus contrincantes y, por supuesto, ¡Ganar!

MECÁNICA Y CONTROLES
Sprint Vector es un juego de carreras en el que compites con ocho corredores portadores de unos patines futuristas que permiten ir a gran velocidad. Tu objetivo será llegar a la meta el primero, ya sea corriendo más que nadie o no dejando que los demás lo hagan. Es un juego frenético, gráficamente estable, divertido y lo mas importante: No marea. 

Survios ha creado una nueva tecnología para este título a la que ha llamado “Fluid Locomotion”. Según su descripción permite al usuario alcanzar velocidades muy altas sin ninguna molestia física, y sin duda lo consigue. Saltamos desniveles increíbles, escalamos paredes con gran facilidad, volamos como Superman, y todo esto con una sensación de velocidad constante y cero náuseas. Hay que añadir que, si no esquivamos y chocamos contra algún obstáculo, sí que se puede crear algún desequilibrio por el cambio brusco de velocidad que algunos jugadores pueden no tolerar bien.

Para aprender a manejarlo, el juego nos presenta unos tutoriales que nos enseñarán a correr lo más rápido posible, a saltar, escalar, volar y a machacar a nuestros contrincantes. 

Los controles son fáciles de aprender pero algo más complejos de aplicar, un mal salto nos puede sacar de la pista si no frenamos a tiempo, de forma que perderemos la ventaja que teníamos en la carrera. Así que en poco tiempo ya estás agitando los brazos para intentar ser el primero. Es un juego físicamente exigente; para desplazarse hay que mover los brazos como si corrieras, de arriba a abajo para impulsarte y saltar, y para escalar hay puntos donde tendremos que agarrarnos si queremos llegar a otros más altos. También podemos driftear para coger mejor las curvas o volar para aprovechar las caídas.

Hay varios modos de juego, desde el casual donde puedes correr más tranquilamente para aprender los entresijos de la pista y mejorar tu técnica; el modo desafío donde tienes 9 recorridos donde poner a prueba tus habilidades contra el tiempo y luchar por subir en el ranking; y el modo competitivo, que es donde la cosa se pone más complicada. Correremos en una de las 12 pistas contra otros siete jugadores, ya sea contra la IA u Online, donde la velocidad es una obligación y los fallos se pagan perdiendo posiciones.
 
Para ayudarnos a ganar durante la carrera podemos encontrar distintos powerups al más puro estilo Mario Kart. Ya sean turbos, potenciadores o trampas. Misiles para ralentizar, minas de proximidad, sobrecargas, nitro... En definitiva todo un arsenal de opciones para tener ventaja sobre nuestros rivales y así alzarse con la victoria.

INMERSIÓN Y GRÁFICOS
El mundo de Sprint Vector es muy colorido y con una estética muy conseguida, que no desentona para nada en RV y, con la excusa de viajes interdimensionales, viajaremos por épocas y mundos diferentes. Desde el antiguo Egipto o castillos nevados a fábricas rebosantes de productos químicos. Visualmente no es algo impactante, pero tampoco decepciona. Hay que destacar del apartado gráfico lo increíblemente estable que es el juego, incluso aumentando el escalado de pantalla no hemos tenido ni un solo tirón ni problemas de seguimiento o desincronización con Vive.

Mientras corremos, veremos algunos detalles en el HUD que nos ayudarán a saber como va la carrera: tenemos un velocímetro que nos dirá a qué velocidad vamos con una barra que aumenta y cambia de color para indicarnos la velocidad, la posición en la que vamos y un indicador de la acción que estamos ejecutando o si nos afecta alguna trampa o powerup.

También hay señales visuales para avisarnos de que vamos lo suficientemente rápido, como luces o rayos que aparecen para aumentar la sensación de velocidad. También nos indican los powerups que hemos adquirido y a qué distancia tenemos a los otros corredores. La mayoría del tiempo nos lo pasamos corriendo y fijándonos en los obstáculos que encontramos para esquivarlos, de manera que cumple con lo necesario evitando distraerte de la carrera.

Tenemos 8 personajes a elegir, cada uno con una estética totalmente diferente, desde una DJ galáctica a una rana ninja o un tiburón martillo. Todos ellos bien diferenciados y con unos diseños en general bastante buenos. Cada personaje tiene unas skins que podremos desbloquear a medida que vayamos ganando carreras. Skins por llamarlo de alguna manera, ya que solo son cambios de color en la indumentaria de cada uno que no afectan a la jugabilidad. Es solo por estética.

El diseño de los mapas está muy conseguido, hay atajos escondidos por todo el recorrido, con distintas alturas, así que la verticalidad es importante para encontrar atajos o power ups que permitan ganar ventaja. Hay que añadir que algunas pistas se repiten y son las mismas solo que en el sentido contrario, aunque tenemos nuevos atajos y zonas sólo accesibles de esta forma.

 

Conclusión

Lo más importante es que es un juego divertido con un gran atractivo visual y técnico. Si te gusta el Mario Kart, este título te encantará. Es lo mas parecido ahora mismo en RV y además con un sistema de locomoción que funciona perfectamente (aunque no innova demasiado), y con una exigencia física elevada ya que has de estar moviéndote constantemente.

En contra del titulo hay que decir que no va a tener localización en español, ni la tendrá por ahora. Apostar por el Online es un recurso habitual para la industria en estos momentos, pero en RV muchos títulos centrados en el juego competitivo acaban muriendo por falta de jugadores. 

Esperemos que no sea el caso en Sprint Vector, y que en sus futuras actualizaciones añada el soporte de juego cruzado entre plataformas para paliar dicha situación.



Pros
+ Extremadamente divertido
+ Muy estable gráficamente
+ Fluid Locomotion

Contras
- No localización
- Centrado en la competitividad
- Sin juego cruzado entre plataformas

Mas analisis en: www.realovirtual.com

39945547.review:
Tagline:
There aren't enough painkillers to compensate for how your arms & shoulders are going to feel in the morning after your first play session!

This game is FUN! And it's AAA quality!
It feels like a brilliant mix of Jet Set Radio + SSX 3 + Mario Kart + Mirror's Edge + Milla's dance party in Psychonauts.
Sprint Vector hits all of the attributes that make a great game.
If nothing else, buy this game for the starting sequence that makes you feel like a rock star celebrity, and play around in the open Skate Park.

PROS
* Controls are good; simple and fitting for Vive controllers. Techniques like jumping & drifting are easily learned in the tutorials.
* The feel of the motion, momentum, jumps, flings, drifts, flying, and everything FEELS good; satisfying. You feel like a superhero superstar!
* Graphics and models are well designed. Good amount of detail, but not so much that things are ever a pixelated aliased mess at a distance.
* Music is excellent for the game's style. I love this soundtrack -- you can buy it, it's 43 tracks ranging from 1.5 to 6 minutes long each.
* Characters are fun and look good. Multiple skins for each, some to unlock.
* Voice acting is entertaining & quirky, and not flat nor boring. Fun announcers!
* Tutorials are explained both with audio speaking to you and showing you what to do on a video screen in front of you. Perfect for VR.
* Single player mode with AI, challenge tracks, 8-human online multiplayer matching, and Steam-Friends-Only By-Invite modes. You & friends can even just hangout and chat & play in the Skate Park and not do races at all. Love the freedom.

NEUTRAL
* While the controls are easy to learn, mastering them requires a learning curve. The harder tracks will throw a lot of combinations of techniques at you back-to-back-to-back!
* Like all interesting racing games, you need to play through the tracks many times to get used to the layouts and learn the tricks. That's part of the fun of leveling your brain up.

CONS
* As I said: There aren't enough painkillers to compensate for how your arms & shoulders are going to feel in the morning after your first long play session!
* Watching your performance plummet after a handful of back-to-back competitive races as real life muscle fatigue takes over. ;-)
* Wanting to keep playing and physically having to stop. =(
* Increased water bill because you'll be taking long, ice cold showers after every 1-hour Sweat Vector session to cool down. And guzzling gallons of water after, too. ;-)


On VR simulation sickness from artificial locomotion:
I don't feel any VR sim sickness!
I am sometimes susceptible to VR sim sickness from artificial locomotions, depending on the game. Sprint Vector didn't give me any problems.
However if someone who gets sim sickness from any and all artificial locomotion types, they might want to be wary. Hey, Steam has the <2 hour refund policy. Try it out.

39940298.review:
I've spent a good amount of time in Sprint Vector so I thought I'd give a brief review. I'll waste no time and get to some scores, ranked from 1 to 5. I am in no way affiliated with the devs and this is totally unbiased. I'm reviewing as an HTC Vive player. I did a gameplay video if anyone cares to check it out, link at the bottom.


[b] Graphics: 5/5 [/b] - The visuals, effects and animations are amazing. Such, such a polished game on the visual front. The maps are incredible. Handcrafted, no repetitive cut-and-paste portions with LOTS of detail. The characters are unique with a lot of creativity behind their looks and personalities. 


[b] Tutorial: 5/5 [/b] - The game might seem simple at first glance, but their is actually quite a bit to learn. Thankfully, the tutorial does an amazing job at covering everything you need to know, with NO READING. All audio with a video guide to show you the controls. That's the way tutorials should be in VR. Not walls of text.


[b] Gameplay: 5/5 [/b] - This game is easily my favorite e-sport multiplayer game. Super fun, competitive gameplay. Single player and multiplayer options. The races are wacky, and even have some Mario Kart-like elements to them where you can shoot/stun opponents. The main abilities are: Sprinting, Braking, Jumping, Flying, Climbing, and Shooting. Besides standard races, there are also challenges you can do solo. A game like this will offer a lot of replayability as well.  


[b] Controls: 4/5 [/b] - The controls are great, but definitely require practice. I docked 1 point because turning sharp corners can be tough and trying not to "sprint" and move slowly to avoid being knocked off ledges/obstacles can get a little frustrating, but I think I just need more practice. Some of the more advanced maps will definitely require mastering the games controls.


[b] A.I.: 4/5 [/b] - The A.I. is quite good but doesn't matter a whole lot because I think most people will want to play online against other people. That's where the game will shine.


[b] Sound: 5/5 [/b] - Great music, sound effects and the goofy characters are voice-acted well. No complaints.


[b] Difficulty: 3/5 [/b] - This is one of those games that's easy to learn, but difficult to master. That's not to discourage anyone though. I'm not very good but still think it's a blast. I can usually get 1st or 2nd place on the "basic" difficulty maps, proof in the video below :P 


In summary, I am very impressed with Sprint Vector. I knew little about the game going into it and that's when I sometimes enjoy a new game the most. It's fun for rookies and pros, competitive or casual play and I can't recommend it enough. [b] Here is my gameplay video if anyone cares to check it out. --> [/b] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zW74bmSV93w

39937301.review:
A really high quality game, just as expected from Survios. There are many controls, but they're intuitive, easy to remember- mastering them for intense situations is the real challenge. You have to be ready to dodge/take advantage of, both the map obstacles, and player placed traps. The available maps are very diverse and challenging- everything you learn in the tutorials should be used in these maps for maximum efficiency, giving you the edge in the race.

Recommend getting this if you like games that make you workout without even realizing it.

39935959.review: This game is a real workout, and the movement system is easy to learn but hard to master. Absolutely no discomfort, not even from drifting or turning in flight, even though those actions rotate your point of view
